awd_titl_txt: Broadening Participation Research Project: STEP into STEM, Investigating Successful Transitions and Effective Pathways into STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
Researchers at North Carolina A&T State University will conduct a longitudinal study using big data analytics to advance the knowledge and evidence base for successful strategies to encourage underrepresented minorities to pursue STEM pathways. The goals of the project are to characterize and understand pathways to STEM, assess STEM intervention effectiveness at universities across the nation based on institutional system/program metrics for student success, and recommend ways to increase the number of underrepresented minority women pursuing STEM degrees and careers. The study will examine factors that influence transitions to STEM for undecided/non-STEM students and demonstrate specific systematic/programmatic interventions that are effective. The research will be guided by a triangulation of social cognitive career theory, student persistence theory, human capital theory, and vocational anticipatory socialization theory. The project is an innovative approach to better understanding factors that motivate students to elect STEM degree programs, and it is expected to develop a core set of best practices metrics for STEM transitions and pathways. 

The primary data sources for the study are the High School Longitudinal Survey and the Beginning Postsecondary Students Survey. The data will be analyzed to examine student pathways into STEM, with a focus on students who are undecided about their majors upon entering community college and four-year degree programs.  The specific research questions are (1) what are the academic, socioeconomic, and demographic supports and barriers for underrepresented minorities (URM)and undecided/non-STEM major transitions to STEM?; (2) what effective pathways and higher education institutional systems/programs support URMs, undecided/non-STEM successful transitions to STEM?; (3) which institutions have data-based evidence to support their best practice intervention strategies?; (4) what implementable strategies will support successful transitions and effective pathways into STEM, particularly for URMs and undecided/non-STEM students from minority serving institutions?; and (5) what shared metrics are recommended for institutions to use nationally to assess successful transitions and effective pathways for URMs into STEM?  Analytical techniques will include Random Forest, Principal Component Analysis, XGBoost, and Deep Learning to analyze the large datasets and conduct the meta studies on the variables. The study results could impact policy and practice at higher education institutions at large.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University

por.por_cntn:
In United States over the past decade, STEM expertise jobs have grown by 34%. This represents a continuing national shift to a larger, more diverse, well-prepared, and STEM-capable workforce to maintain the United States global competitiveness and economy. To achieve this end, billions of federal dollars have been spent to attract and keep students in STEM fields including extensive study and analysis of the STEM “pipeline”. See the traditional image of the "STEM Pipeline Model."  The hypothesis of the “pipeline model” is that if one increases the number/percentage of students entering the pipeline near the source of the pipe (which begins during the middle-school years), while also taking measures to make the attrition (or leaking) less pronounced, there will be a significant rise in STEM graduates from college to the STEM workforce (GAO, 2012). Evidence indicates that this approach is only marginally effective at best, as the demand for STEM workers continues to outpace the STEM-prepared graduate pool.This is particularly true for under-represented minorities (URMs) in STEM.  Currently, the number of URMs in existing STEM pipelines is insufficient to address underrepresentation in both college STEM programs and the STEM workforce, particularly given that women and URMs are known to opt out of STEM majors at disproportionately higher rates and enter at lower rates than their majority counterparts.  In 2011, only 26% of STEM workers were women and only 9% were minorities (non-White, non-Asian). 

The leaky STEM pipeline model is pessimistic in the sense that it assumes accruing losses that can perhaps be alleviated through educational and psychosocial interventions, but it precludes the possibility of alternative pathways to STEM that could inform new bold, large-scale, national initiatives in K-20 education. This research identified some of these alternative pathways using a Social-Cognitive Career Theory framework (Lent et al., 2000) and innovative data science applied to a post-secondary education longitudinal dataset from the National Center for Education Statistics (NCES). Influencing factors/variables, combinations of factors and their impacts, and a core set of metrics for STEM transitions and pathways were hypothesized to inform the creation of a new STEM pathway paradigm. See the image "Alternative Pathways to STEM (APS) Model."  This paradigm could then inform new STEM preventive and active recruitment interventions at every step along the STEM educational route, including at the community college and 4-year college/university levels.  Such interventions can be particularly effective to broaden the participation of underrepresented minorities (URMs). In addition, this research identifies the most salient demographic, economic, and academic indicators for different populations of students.

It was determined that there were actuallly more student flux into STEM, than out of STEM in this research.  The strength of a students math and science academic background was a major determinant of successful transitions to STEM degrees.  Students that transfer institutions during their post-secondary career tend to migrate to STEM (through an understanding of math, science, and the allure of a better paying job).  The use of Community College education is a specific experience that results in an influx of STEM students achieving degrees in STEM.  This is one of many observations related to the academic, demographic and socio-economic backgrounds of nearly 17,000 students analyzed in this project with Computational Data Science techniques.


Last Modified: 10/29/2022
Modified by: Gregory H Monty
